newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq ready to sign oil deals after UN green light.
newsitem.headline: Iraq ready to sign oil deals after UN green light.

text.p: Iraq will sign oil sales contracts as soon as the United Nations approves Baghdad's oil pricing formula, Iraq's Oil Minister Amir Muhammed Rasheed said on Wednesday.
"There are several oil companies (whose representatives) are currently in Baghdad seeking to buy Iraqi crude and we have many offers (from oil firms)," Rasheed said.
U.N. overseers are expected to formally recommend the Iraqi price formula to the Security Council's sanctions committee on Iraq sometime on Wednesday morning in New York, diplomats say.
The committee then has 48 hours to raise any objections to the formula, submitted by Baghdad on Tuesday, or it automatically becomes valid.
Rasheed said as soon as the approval is given Iraq "will be able to sign oil contracts" with states and oil companies.
The oil-for-food deal, which went into effect last December, allows Iraq limited oil sales worth $2 billion over every six months.
The proceeds buy food and medicine for ordinary Iraqis, hard-hit by U.N. sanctions imposed for Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
"Priority (in signing these contracts) would be given to companies and states which adopt postive stand from Iraq," Rasheed said.
Japanese oil traders said a representative from Mitsubuishi Corp was in Baghdad to discuss oil contracts with Iraq's State Oil and Marketing Organisation, on behalf of four large Japanese refiners.
But it was not clear what other companies or states were in the Iraqi capital to discuss buying oil.
